da-qi-abolished.name: Da Qi Abolished

quote.text: In Tianhui 15, an edict abolished Qi and demoted Liu Yu to King of Shu.

da-qi-abolished.rulesTextOverride:
If Liu Yu has a tucked :dagger: and a :jin-foot:/:jin-horse:/:jin-ship: is present in :daqi-capital:, trash [[liu-yu-puppet-emperor-of-da-qi-star]] and tuck this in front of Liu Yu. Then replace all :daqi-foot:/:daqi-horse:/:daqi-ship: with :jin-foot:/:jin-horse:/:jin-ship: everywhere.

Otherwise, take 1 :coin: from Liu Yu and give it to any :jin: player as tribute.

start-yue-fei.name: Yue Fei, Loyal Song Officer

quote.text: “If civil officials don’t love money and military men don’t fear death, the realm will be at peace.”

start-yue-fei.rulesTextOverride:
Add [[yue-fei-cuts-horses-legs-star]] to your hand.
Recruit one :song-foot: in 5 separate cities without :dot: or :star:.
Place Yue Fei in Ezhou or a city adjacent to Ezhou.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.
Tuck this card.

start-qin-hui.name: Qin Hui, Jin Captive

quote.text: “Let the South keep to the South, the North to the North.”

start-qin-hui.rulesTextOverride:
Add [[qin-hui-treacherous-minister-star]] to your hand.
Place one :rebel-foot: in Bianjing.
Place :jin-capital: in Shangjing or Yanjing.
Place Qin Hui in any city with :dot:.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.
Tuck this card.

start-wuzhu.name: Wuzhu, Jin General

quote.text: He drove the Song ruler onto a sea island and, in the end, fixed the Huai as the boundary.

start-wuzhu.rulesTextOverride:
Add [[wuzhu-fire-arrows-star]] to your hand.
Recruit 4 :jin-horse: in any city with :dot:.
Place Wuzhu in any city with :dot:.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.
Tuck this card.

start-talan.name: Talan, Jin General

quote.text: Impulsive to the end, he fell into treason; when the plot failed he fled south—only confirming his dealings with the Song. Alas!

start-talan.rulesTextOverride:
Add [[talan-back-channel-dealings-star]] to your hand.
Recruit 3 :jin-horse: in any city with :dot:.
Place Talan in any city with :dot:.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.
Tuck this card.

start-liu-yu.name: Liu Yu, Song Official

quote.text: Liu Yu seized the moment for gain; the Jin sought to use him to claim credit—what sense is that?

start-liu-yu.rulesTextOverride:
Add [[liu-yu-sea-routes-map-star]] to your hand.
Place :song-capital: in Huaiyang.
Recruit one :song-ship: in 4 separate water-accessible cities without :dot: or :star:.
Place Liu Yu in Chuzhou or a city adjacent to Chuzhou without :star:.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.
Tuck this card.

quote.text: Require the people to form five‑household bao and compile household registers every three years, with ward and village heads overseeing levies and policing.

liu-yu-puppet-emperor-of-da-qi-star.name: Liu Yu, Puppet Emperor of Da Qi*
liu-yu-puppet-emperor-of-da-qi-star.rulesTextOverride: Choose any Jin-controlled city excluding Shangjing and Yanjing. Place :daqi-capital: there and 3 :daqi-foot:. Place 3 :daqi-foot: and 2 :daqi-ship: in cities adjacent to :daqi-capital: that contain no Song or Rebel pieces (if possible). Shuffle the Da Qi deck into the draw deck. Trash [[liu-yu-defects-to-the-jin]] and tuck this card in front of Liu Yu’s player.

quote.text: They performed the investiture with full rites, established Liu Yu as Emperor of Great Qi, and made Daming the capital.

li-cheng-rebels-star.name: Li Cheng Rebels*
li-cheng-rebels-star.rulesTextOverride:
Destroy one non‑rebel :foot:/:horse:/:ship: in Yangzhou. All other non‑rebel pieces in Yangzhou retreat. Then add 2 :rebel-foot: and 1 :rebel-ship: in Yangzhou.
Then choose one: Move; Raid; Assault.
Then tuck this card.

quote.text: In the Jiang–Huai region bandits rose up in swarms; Li Cheng was especially fierce, holding more than ten prefectures across Jiang–Huai and Huxiang.

maritime-trade-offices.name: Maritime Trade Offices
maritime-trade-offices.rulesTextOverride: Gain 1 :coin: for each :maritime: city your faction controls: Mingzhou, Quanzhou, Fuzhou, Guangzhou. Then gain +1 :coin: per :admin: tucked.

quote.text: In the fifth month, the court restored the maritime trade offices (Shibo) for Liangzhe and Fujian.

guangxi-horse-imports.name: Guangxi Horse Imports
guangxi-horse-imports.rulesTextOverride:
If your faction controls Guangzhou: You may pay up to 3 :coin: to upgrade any of your faction’s :foot: to :horse: anywhere on the map, one per :coin: paid.
:admin:: For each :admin: you have tucked, you may pay one additional :coin: and upgrade one additional :foot: to :horse:.
Then choose one: Move; Raid; Assault.

quote.text: Emperor Gaozong ordered Li Yu to purchase horses among the Guangxi tribes and to establish a stock‑raising office at Yongzhou.

tea-tickets-and-fees.name: Tea Tickets and Fees
tea-tickets-and-fees.rulesTextOverride: Gain 1 :coin: for every 2 :tea: cities your faction controls (rounded down): Jianzhou, Shaoxing, Hangzhou, Tanzhou, Chengdu, Lizhou, Xingyuan, Nanchang, Jiujiang. Then gain +1 :coin: per :admin: tucked.

quote.text: All tea was under prohibition; only in Chuanxia and Lingnan could people buy and sell for personal use; export beyond the frontier was forbidden.

zhang-bangchang-ordered-to-drink-poison-.name: Zhang Bangchang Ordered to Drink Poison*
zhang-bangchang-ordered-to-drink-poison-.rulesTextOverride:
Remove a :rebel-foot: from Bianjing. 
Shuffle the Jianyan deck into the draw pile. 
Give [[liu-yu-defects-to-the-jin]] to Liu Yu’s player. 
Tuck this card.

quote.text: Facing north, Bangchang kowtowed to receive the investiture; he assumed a false throne as Great Chu and planned to make Jinling the capital.

liu-yu-defects-to-the-jin.name: Liu Yu Defects to the Jin
liu-yu-defects-to-the-jin.rulesTextOverride:
Convert 2 :song-foot:/:song-horse:/:song-ship: to the same type of :jin-foot:/:jin-horse:/:jin-ship: in Liu Yu’s location.
Destroy 1 :song-foot:/:song-horse:/:song-ship: in Liu Yu’s location.
All other :song-foot:/:song-horse:/:song-ship: and :song-character: in Liu Yu’s location retreat.
Trash the [[start-liu-yu]] card and tuck this card in front of Liu Yu in its place.

quote.text: He killed his general and surrendered to the Jin.

yue-fei-cuts-horses-legs-star.name: Yue Fei Cuts the Horses' Legs*
yue-fei-cuts-horses-legs-star.rulesTextOverride:
Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.
Keep this card when played.
Destroy an enemy :horse: or :foot: in a city adjacent to Yue Fei’s location.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.

quote.text: Fei ordered the infantry to go in with blades, not look up, and cut only at the horses’ legs… the enemy was decisively routed.

yue-fei-cuts-horses-legs-star.playConditionMessage: Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.

qin-hui-treacherous-minister-star.name: Qin Hui, Treacherous Minister*
qin-hui-treacherous-minister-star.rulesTextOverride:
Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.
Keep this card when played.
Retrieve a :dagger: card from the discard pile and tuck it in front of any other player, only if Qin Hui is in a city with :song-capital:.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.

quote.text: Insidious as a hidden pit; his schemes were unfathomable.

qin-hui-treacherous-minister-star.playConditionMessage: Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.

wuzhu-fire-arrows-star.name: Wuzhu's Fire Arrows*
wuzhu-fire-arrows-star.rulesTextOverride:
Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.
Keep this card when played.
Destroy an enemy :jin-ship: adjacent to Wuzhu.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.

quote.text: He selected good archers in light boats and shot fire arrows at the awnings on Han Shizhong’s ships; the awnings caught and burned.

wuzhu-fire-arrows-star.playConditionMessage: Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.

talan-back-channel-dealings-star.name: Talan's Back Channel Dealings*
talan-back-channel-dealings-star.rulesTextOverride:
Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.
Keep this card when played.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.
You may draw a card. If you do, an enemy player draws a card and you gain 1 :coin:.

quote.text: Zong Bi observed that Talan had dealings with the Song, exchanging gifts.

talan-back-channel-dealings-star.playConditionMessage: Cannot be played with a * card in hand.

liu-yu-sea-routes-map-star.name: Liu Yu's Sea Routes Map*
liu-yu-sea-routes-map-star.rulesTextOverride:
Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.
Keep this card when played.
Recruit 1 :foot: in Liu Yu’s location; OR if Liu Yu’s location is water-accessible, you may pay 2 :coin: to recruit 1 :ship: there.
Draw up to a hand of 6 cards.

quote.text: Yu presented a Sea Routes Map and wooden models of warships to the Jin emperor Dan.

liu-yu-sea-routes-map-star.playConditionMessage: Cannot be played with other * cards in hand.

mengan-mouke-system.name: Meng’an–Mouke System
mengan-mouke-system.rulesTextOverride:
Recruit 1 :jin-horse: at Shangjing if Shangjing is Jin‑controlled.
Then Move.

quote.text: Organized under Meng’an and Mouke, military and civil registers are unified and offices pass down the generations to provide forces for campaigns and frontier garrisons.
The Sifang Office oversaw relay stations and post horses across the routes.

state-grain-markets.name: State Grain Markets
state-grain-markets.rulesTextOverride:
If you have 5 or more cards in hand, discard a non-* card and gain 1 :coin:.
Otherwise, draw 2 cards.

quote.text: In plentiful years buy at higher prices; in lean years release at lower, to stabilize grain prices.

imperial-salt-monopoly.name: Imperial Salt Monopoly
imperial-salt-monopoly.rulesTextOverride: Gain 1 :coin: for each :salt: city your faction controls: Cangzhou, Haizhou, Taizhou, Fuzhou, Quanzhou, and Taiyuan. Then gain +1 :coin: per :admin: tucked.

quote.text: Under the Jin system, among the ten categories of monopolized goods, salt ranked first.

imperial-court-threatened.name: Imperial Court Threatened
imperial-court-threatened.rulesTextOverride:
Choose one:
- Recruit 1 :foot: in your faction’s :capital: (only if your :capital: is not enemy-controlled).
- Move your faction’s :capital: up to 2 steps along any connections to a city with no enemy or neutral units.

quote.text: In the tenth month, the emperor boarded boats and went to the Huai; the Empress Dowager arrived at Yangzhou.
